## **Constituents**: basic structure in syntax
<br>
.pull-left[
**constituent**: a group of words that <span style="color:green"><b>acts together</b></span> as a **unit** <br><br>
- Consider the following sentences. What is the **subject** of each sentence?<br><br>
1. *Francisco <span style="color:blue"><b>studies linguistics</b><span>.*
2. *The tall boy <span style="color:blue"><b>studies linguistics</b><span>.*
3. *The tall boy from New Jersey <span style="color:blue"><b>studies linguistics</b><span>.*
4. *The tall boy named Francisco <span style="color:blue"><b>studies linguistics</b><span>.*
5. *The tall boy that I met last week <span style="color:blue"><b>studies linguistics</b><span>.*<br><br>
]

## **Constituents**: basic structure in syntax
<br>
.pull-left[
**constituent**: a group of words that <span style="color:green"><b>acts together</b></span> as a **unit** <br><br>
- Consider the following sentences. What is the **subject** of each sentence?<br><br>
1. *<u>Francisco</u> <span style="color:blue"><b>studies linguistics</b><span>.*
2. *<u>The tall boy</u> <span style="color:blue"><b>studies linguistics</b><span>.*
3. *<u>The tall boy from New Jersey</u> <span style="color:blue"><b>studies linguistics</b><span>.*
4. *<u>The tall boy named Francisco</u> <span style="color:blue"><b>studies linguistics</b><span>.*
5. *<u>The tall boy that I met last week</u> <span style="color:blue"><b>studies linguistics</b><span>.* <br><br>

- SUBJECT can be **one** or **many** words, but they all <span style="color:green"><b>act together</b></span> to describe a single concept
]

<div style="text-align:center;">
<img src="../pic/0926/syntax2.jpg" width="45%"> <br><br>

## **Phrases**: types of constituents
<br>
.pull-left[
- Each phrase has a main word or **head**<br><br>

- Phrases are named after the head word's **part of speech** (PoS):<br><br>
  - **noun phrase** (<span style="color:green"><b>NP</b></span>): *<u>man</u>, the <u>man</u>, the happy <u>man</u>, the <u>man</u> with the hat*<br><br>
  - **prepositional phrase** (<span style="color:purple"><b>PP</b></span>): *<u>into</u> the forest, <u>by</u> the author, <u>for</u> good luck*<br><br>
  - **verb phrase** (<span style="color:blue"><b>VP</b></span>): *<u>eats</u>, <u>eats</u> pizza, <u>eats</u> quickly, <u>eats</u> pizza quickly at noon*<br><br>
  - **adjective phrase** (<span style="color:orange"><b>AdjP</b></span>): *<u>happy</u>, <u>ugly</u>*<br><br>
  - **adverb phrase** (<span style="color:brown"><b>AdvP</b></span>): *<u>quickly</u>, <u>happily</u>*
]
  
.pull-right[
- **one constituent can contain another**:<br><br>
  - <u>*the man with the hat*</u> (<span style="color:green"><b>NP</b></span>) contains <u>*with the hat*</u> (<span style="color:purple"><b>PP</b></span>), which contains <u>*the hat*</u> (<span style="color:green"><b>NP</b></span>)<br><br>
  - <u>*eats quickly at noon*</u> (<span style="color:blue"><b>VP</b></span>)contains <u>*quickly*</u> (<span style="color:brown"><b>AdvP</b></span>) and <u>*at noon*</u> (<span style="color:purple"><b>PP</b></span>)<br><br>
<img src="../pic/0926/hat.png" width="45%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<img src="../pic/0926/noon.png" width="45%">
]

## **Constituency Tests**
<br><br>
.pull-left[
- There are four tests to **identify** whether a group of words IS a **constituent** or NOT: <br><br>
  - Replacement (substitution) test <br><br>
  - Movement test <br><br>
  - Stand-alone test <br><br>
  - Coordination test <br><br>
- **These don't work 100% of the time**, and some tests work better with some sentences. Hence, you might have to try several
]
.pull-right[
<img src="../pic/0926/brocco.png" width="85%">
]
<br>
### *<b><span style="color:green">[The lugubrious man]</span></b>* ate *<b><span style="color:blue">[his bland broccoli]</span></b>*.

---
## **Replacement (Substitution) Test**
<br>
### *<b><span style="color:green">[The lugubrious man]</span></b>* ate *<b><span style="color:blue">[his bland broccoli]</span></b>*.
<br>
.pull-left[
- **replacement**: replace a group of words with a **pro-form**. If it works, they are one constituent <br><br>
- **pro-from**: <u>pronoun</u> or other generic expression like <u>there</u>, <u>like that</u>, <u>do</u>, <u>do that</u>, <u>that way</u><br><br>
  - *<span style="color:blue">[The lugubrious man]</span> ate his bland broccoli* → *<span style="color:blue">[He]</span> ate his bland broccoli.* <br><br>
  - *The lugubrious man <span style="color:blue">[ate his bland]</span> broccoli* → *The lugubrious man <span style="color:blue">[???] broccoli.*<br><br>
  - Try the replacement test with  [bland broccoli], [the lugurbious] and [man ate]
]
.pull-right[
<img src="../pic/0926/broccotree.png" width="85%"> <br><br>
'*The lugubrious man ate his bland broccoli*.'
]
---
## **Movement Test**
<br>
### *<b><span style="color:green">[The lugubrious man]</span></b>* ate *<b><span style="color:blue">[his bland broccoli]</span></b>*.
<br>
.pull-left[
- **movement test**: move a group of words to a different part of the sentence<br><br>
- You may have to add **extra** words to support this movement<br><br>
  - → *The person who <u>ate his bland broccoli</u> is <span style="color:blue">[the lugubrious man]</span>*.<br><br>
  - → \* *<u>Man</u> who <u>ate his bland broccoli</u> is <span style="color:blue">[the lugubrious]</span>*.<br><br>
  - Try the movement test with [his bland broccoli], [his bland] and [man ate]
]
.pull-right[
<img src="../pic/0926/broccotree.png" width="85%"> <br><br>
'*The lugubrious man ate his bland broccoli*.'
]

---

<br>

### *<b><span style="color:orange">[Today]</span></b> <b><span style="color:green">[the dog]</span></b>* ate *<b><span style="color:blue">[the sandwich]</span></b>*.

How do we know whether it was <b><span style="color:orange">'today'</span></b> moved or <b><span style="color:green">'the dog ate the sandwich'</span></b>?
<br><br>
<img src="../pic/0926/dog.png" width="60%">
]

.pull-right[

]

## **Stand Alone Test**
<br>
### *<b><span style="color:green">[The lugubrious man]</span></b>* ate *<b><span style="color:blue">[his bland broccoli]</span></b>*.
<br>
.pull-left[
- **stand alone test**: come up with a question that can be answered by just saying the group of words you want to test **on its own** <br><br>
  - → *Who <u>ate his bland broccoli</u>?*<br>
  *<span style="color:blue">[the lugubrious man]</span>!* <br><br>
  - Try the stand alone test with [his bland broccoli], [the lugubrious] or [man ate]?
]
.pull-right[
<img src="../pic/0926/broccotree.png" width="85%"> <br><br>
'*The lugubrious man ate his bland broccoli*.'
]

---
## **Coordination Test**
<br>
### *<b><span style="color:green">[The lugubrious man]</span></b>* ate *<b><span style="color:blue">[his bland broccoli]</span></b>*.
<br>
.pull-left[
- **coordination test**: coordinating conjunctions like <b><span style="color:green">and</span></b> or <b><span style="color:green">or</span></b> will always join two words or phrases of **the same type**<br><br>
- If a group of words is a constituent, we are able to insert another phrase of the same type joined with <b><span style="color:green">and</span></b> or <b><span style="color:green">or</span></b> <br><br>
  - → *<span style="color:blue">[the lugubrious man]</span> and <span style="color:orange">[Rumpelstilzchen]</span> <u>ate</u> their <u>bland broccoli</u>*.<br><br>
  - Try the coordination test with [his bland broccoli], [man ate] and [his bland]
]
.pull-right[
<img src="../pic/0926/broccotree.png" width="85%"> <br><br>
'*The lugubrious man ate his bland broccoli*.'
]
